It is rare that a stock becomes as hot as Tesla in 2020, I think Volkswagen in 2008 is the last time I remember anything like it. Therefore, putting a value on volatility is incredibly more difficult as markets diverge from normal "random walk"/Brownian motion - like behavior and become unstable. Didier Sornette in his brilliant but arguably out of left field book "Why Stock Markets Crash" compared the behavior in these scenarios to balancing a pen on your finger: it is not a matter of if, but when, the pen drops. The binomial path every trading session is not between up/down a certain multiple of sigma, but an increasingly large gain with high probability, versus total collapse. The FT reported on Sep 3rd that Baillie Gifford, Tesla’s biggest independent shareholder, had cut its investment in the electric car maker, generating profits of about $17bn in just eight months after a six-fold surge in the company’s valuation. 

https://www.ft.com/content/e3cb3bc5-a185-4e2a-8ed8-45e48840ef9d This could be likened to the sailor accidentally eating a Tulip bulb in the 1600s. Or maybe not, and we are in for a final "super spike"? I find it interesting that if German carmaker Daimler Benz (Mercedes) had not sold its 4% Tesla share in 2014, this would now be worth more than the rest of Daimler. Strange times. But what does the market think? Here are the September options on Tesla for the relevant call strikes. I then use the implied volatility to extend the probability to September 22nd instead of the actual expiration on September 18th. Finally, I modify for my own bearish bias. Note that Tesla closed at $330 but I am correcting the probability for the new pre open price of $353  Sep 18 $400 Call @ 330: $8.66 - implied vol 134% - delta as per Sep 22nd value, $352 market: 35%
Sep 18 $450 Call @ 330: $3.98 - implied vol 141% - delta as per Sep 22nd value, $352 market: 21%
Sep 18 $500 Call @ 330: $2.27 - implied vol 153% - delta as per Sep 22nd value, $352 market: 14%
Sep 18 $550 Call @ 330: $1.41 - implied vol 165% - delta as per Sep 22nd value, $352 market: 10% How to interpret this: the option market implied chance of Tesla being above $550 on Sep 22nd is 10% assuming that the same volatility is valid for Sep 22nd and $352 that worked for Sep 18th and $330, something that exaggerates the probability slightly. The chance of >$500 is 14%, therefore, the chance that Tesla is between $500-$550 is 4% etc.  To account for my bearish bias that the "blow off top" is in and the sale of Baillie Gifford was the significant exit event I am using the probabilities of September 18th as valid for September 22nd, and yesterday's closing value instead of the pre open, but otherwise "listen" to the market.

Options expiring on the 25th of September has a flat risk reversal skew, with ATM trading at 130% vol. Extrapolating from this we can roughly estimate where the market thinks Tesla will trade on the 22nd.

There are only 3 things to think about in regard to this question. BATTERY DAY, BATTERY DAY, BATTERY DAY. I will spell it out for you -  EV's run on batteries, EV's costs are driven by battery costs, batteries determine range anxiety, batteries determine resale value. Any stepwise change in basic battery technology is a big deal. If TSLA can demonstrate a meaningful change in battery technology they will be rewarded by the market.

To model the highly random process which is Tesla returns, I decided to use a random walk which draws from the past distribution of returns. I used returns over the past couple months. Now, there are certainly problems with this assumption. Tesla has been on a meteoric rise as of late, and many people believe that this will not continue, or will even mean revert. If I thought this, then I might need to use a different strategy on top of the random walk, because otherwise I would not be taking into account the possibility of a significant downturn. But I don't see a reason to suspect that Tesla's momentum will not continue. At this point the stock's behavior is not tied to fundamentals but instead to "hype" around it which is largely fueled by retail investors. And we have seen before that rises in an asset's price driven by retail demand can continue far longer than people expect them to. Consider Bitcoin, which rose from hundreds of dollars in 2016 to around $20k in 2018. I will need to update this forecast significantly if Tesla's behavior changes – for instance there could be a drop tomorrow caused by its failure to be included in the S&P 500.

Similiar to my colleagues, I note that there are several ways to tackle this problem - for example, we can use historical price data to forecast the price path of TSLA, or we can use options delta as a measure of finishing ITM for certain strikes. While using historical data to forecast future prices can lead to a variety of creative input in terms of how we want to model our data - I believe that the option's delta suffices as a measure that encapsulates a wide variety of modelling techniques. Further, one major factor that would've impacted TSLA's price was the inclusion in the S&P 500 index, however, we now know that TSLA was not included in the latest re balancing for the S&P.  According to options delta we get the above distribution. From the options delta we get the follow

The 9/25 expiry currently trades at a ~130% implied vol, while the 9/18 expiry trades at a ~110% vol (not exactly sure what the event is that's pushing up 9/25 vol). There also doesn't seem to be much of a skew factor (ATM call = ATM put) which leads us to believe that prices are roughly normally distributed.   If we use option delta as probability of finishing in the money, we can get a rough approximation of the individual probabilities of each bucket by averaging the deltas of the 9/18 and 9/25 expiries. What we do have to consider, however, is that the options pricing now are not factoring in after hours trading on Friday when it was announced that Tesla would not be joining the S&P. This was also a significant event for TSLA and thus implied vols will drop on Tuesday as well, which will need to be factored in. Taking all this account, we have the rough distribution above. I'll be sure to update this once market opens on Tuesday.

There are two obvious ways of estimating this, (1) a random walk, (2)  by looking at option prices.
I first implemented the random walk. The two main problems here are estimating the future daily returns and the volatility that TSLA will realize between now and Sep 22. For returns, I simply chose to use  the S&P500 over the last 
 5 years. This assumes that TSLA will have market returns which I am not sure is accurate given how it has moved over the past few months but I dont think I am better able to predict this value myself. For volatility I looked at 30-50 day realized volon bloomberg which is ~80. I added 10% to this due to the potential vol event regarding the S&P 500 add.  For the options I used sep 18 and sep 25 expirations and option delta as the probability they would finish itm. Again finding the correct value for volatility is the main problem here. In this case I decided just to go with market IV. I took the average probability from each of these methods to arrive at my results

Baseline: Predicting Tesla stock price is very difficult given that due to immense retail flow it has been trading at multiples and valuations that are very hard to justify using fundamental analysis. However, this has been the case for years now, therefore we need to find other ways to put a probability distribution around the stock price. A common way to do it is to use implied option prices and the values that market implies. Option deltas can often be used as an approximate for the probability that the markets imply for the event to occur. We use these values to come up with a probability distribution for the price. There are two main reason why such method could be used and might prove valid: (1) the wisdom of the crowd cannot be underestimated and has proven to be often right, (2) given how detached Tesla is from its fundamental valuation, it is the market that is driving and deciding about the price and not the other way round. Adjustments:
On Friday 09/04 at 5.15pm ET the S&P decided that Tesla will not be added to the S&P 500. Lots of the recent price rallies have been driven by the fact that investors were betting on the inclusion of the stock (which would  have meant lots of inflow from funds tracking the index), but given that this will not occur investors might start to sell off their positions. Conclusion: Putting these two factors together, we predict the distribution stipulated above.

Question: 
Base rate: I simulated the price of Tesla at time t as a Geometric Brownian motion. For mu the percentage drift and sigma the percentage volatility I used historical returns of the stocks on different horizons: from July 1st, Jan 1st 20 or Jan1st 19. For each case, I have then run 100000 Monte Carlo simulations to get some probabilities for each range. For Jan1st 20 (jan 1st 19) got the following proba: Less than $400.00 31% (30), Between $400.00 and $450.00, inclusive 17% (24), More than $450.00 but less than $500.00 18% (20), Between $500.00 and $550.00 12% (13), More than $550.00 22% (13).  Adjustment
-	This method is really basic and needs to be balanced. TSLA 25 Sept ATM implied volatility (IV) is 133.9, which is in the 98% percentile rank. This means that 98% of the time the IV was lower in the last year than the current level. Implied volatility is trending higher. 
-	We can use the delta as a proxy of the probability of an option to end in the money. As options expire on Friday and the 22 is a Tuesday I equally weighted the probas implied by those 2 expiries. 
18 sept then 25 Sept expiry -> average:
Less than $400.00 37% | 38% -> 37%
Between $400.00 and $450.00, inclusive 58-37=21% | 53-38 = 15% -> 18%
More than $450.00 but less than $500.00 74-58=16% | 65-53 = 12% -> 14%
Between $500.00 and $550.00, inclusive 85-74=11% | 65-74=9% -> 10%
More than $550.00 15% | 26% -> 21%
-	On Sep 22, 2020 at 1:30 PM PDT Tesla, Annual Shareholder Meeting [2] -> I adjusted previous proba slightly to the left for my final prediction [1] https://marketchameleon.com/Overview/TSLA/OptionChain/#:~:text=(TSLA)%20options%3F,the%20derivative%20(an%20option).&text=Correspondingly%2C%20a%20delta%20of%20%2D0.75,On%20Market%20Chameleon's%20Tesla%20Inc.
[2] https://ir.tesla.com/events-and-presentations
Very volatile, but very heavy downside. Not as much on the upside.
Currently 420. No earnings reporting until 22nd. 2 weeks over 400. Now some backlash.

I used TSLA options data to back out the delta, which is the risk neutral probability under current implied volatility levels that the option will end up in the money. This is a rough heuristic after all (see risk neutral vs. real world probability difference here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_finance) and the delta is best for approximation near the strike. However, since I have no strong prior on this and TSLA is very volatile stock (say 130 IV), I am basing my predictions on the market implied (risk-neutral) odds.

Took daily return since start of 2018, found the std and mean, and sampled 12 days from a normal dist with this std and mean to get my price estimate for sep 22. Repeated 100k times to inform probabilities of each bin. Also repeated for data just starting in 2019 and just the last 45 days of data. My guess is a weighted avg of these three, with more weight given to the run where I only used the last 45 days. Plus I'm a TSLA fan so then I needed to skew it by a couple percent -- Sept 22 is TSLA battery day so I would guess there will be a decent amount of retail enthusiasm during that trading day and the lead up. Also potential S&P inclusion makes me skew higher. In total I'll take about 10% from lower bins and add to higher ones

Three weeks is not enough time for a  dramatic shift in opinion or outlook of the company.  There are no earnings calls on the immediate horizon which would change much either.  There will be a correction at some point but I don't believe it will be in the next few weeks.

While Nikkei Business Publications gave Tesla a six-year lead in electronics relative to Toyota and VW, I think the technological advantage might be overstated and not justify a 900% year-on-year increase of its share price.  I think there is a decent probability of competitors to catch up as well as new players like Lucid to emerge. (Lucid provided the battery packs for the entire Formula-E Championship)
 https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a33797162/2021-lucid-air-517-mile-range-113-kwh-battery/
Tesla and Panasonic also seem to have not as a synergetic partnership as it seems.

On second thought, it's unclear to me what is going on in this question. I assume a 5-1 stock split will happen in September, so these bins will have to be divided by 5. Current prices put that at  442.68. Assuming some kind of drive up as shares becomes accessible to non-institutional investors again, 100 shares would cost $44268.
Wrote a nice observation about how a split will pull in more investors, go to Submit   ~ Technical Glitch  ~  Money buys everything but good sense  :) Shall keep a watch on prices

Next week should see the stock split.  Analysts mentioning Tesla being over-priced a lot recently and with the short time frame, this could be volatile. Will monitor daily from next week.
